none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, April 21, 1880
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, April 21, 1880
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 5 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Brenham Graded School, Brenham Tex
April 21st 1880.

My Dear Professor -
Your good letter
like precious ointment reached
me yesterday - I read it with
avidity & enjoyed it immensely -
Today is a legal holiday &
a gala day in general to the
denizens of our city -
The memories of San Jacinto
quicken the pulse of the aged &
the rollicking freedom of a
School holiday intoxicates
the brain of the young, & here
am I, every thing ablaze
with good humor, half inclined
to vociferate: "I love you
much a School boy" - Guess
I was - War'nt you?
'Tis said one of the first

**My Process in Deciphering This Letter**

Alright, let's dive in. My task here is to pull apart this handwritten letter, line by line, and get it down in a clean transcription. First, the header catches my eye: "Brenham Graded School, Brenham Tex." The handwriting on "Graded" is a bit sloppy, maybe it could be "Gradia" or "Gradin". However, considering the historical context, "Brenham Graded School" sounds right, so I will go with that while also noting the ambiguous handwriting on the word "Graded." The date is clear: "April 21st 1880".

Now, onto the body of the letter. The salutation, "My Dear Professor -", is straightforward. Then comes the main content: "Your good letter like precious ointment reached me yesterday - I read it with avidity & enjoyed it immensely -". Ah, the writer has squeezed "like precious ointment" in between the lines. I must transcribe it as faithfully as possible to show that insertion, even though I'll have to put it into the flow of reading to make any sense of it.

Next up, the letter continues describing the day being a holiday: "Today is a legal holiday & a gala day in general to the denizens of our city -". Then comes an evocative passage: "The memories of San Jacinto quicken the pulse of the aged & the rollicking freedom of a School holiday intoxicates the brain of the young, & here am I, every thing ablaze with good humor, half inclined to vociferate: "I love you much a School boy" - Guess I was - War'nt you? 'Tis said one of the first".

The line "I love you much a School boy" gives me pause. I am trying to figure out what they are implying. The handwriting looks like “much,” but maybe it is “such”? I am trying out different phrases. Is it "I love you such a School boy"? No, there is a clear M. Is there a missing word? Is this an idiomatic expression that is now obscure? Maybe the writer meant "I love you much, as a School boy". The handwriting seems clear "m-u-c-h", and it is not, say, a cursive 's' stylized to look like an M.

So I've tried a few things:
* "I love you / much of a School boy."
* "I love you / much as a School boy".
* "I love you / such a School boy"
* "I love you much, a School boy"

So, here is what I have decided:
1. I will transcribe it as "much" due to handwriting, but I note the phrasing as unusual, but the safest method of accuracy is just transcribing exactly what it is.
2. The letter is a snapshot of someone feeling youthful and exuberant because of the holiday.

Now I'm ready to present a clear transcription.

[Header: 2]

indications of age is a disposition
to fight our battles over again -
I doubt the philosophy of that
"Saying" - I think it depends
not to much on how the battle
was fought as how it came out -
What do you say? I vote for
how it "comes out" - But
every man is a hero, & is
worthy of an Epic - if not from
poor old blind Homer or the
facile Virgil - or at least from
Milton who tuned his lyre
& sang of Eden & its purity -
Man & his fall - heaven & its
glorified saints - hell and its
blighted spirits - I love to
follow Homer - as he sings
of Trojan wars - battles
fought without gun-powder -
(I've smelt much worse things than gun
powder)

**Okay, here's the transcription thinking process, distilled:**

I'm starting with a clear understanding of the task: transcribe this handwritten text, maintaining its original form as much as possible, following very specific HTML rules, and, crucially, avoiding any commentary. The image itself is a handwritten letter, seemingly a personal reflection, and page "2" is small in the top right corner.

First, I go line-by-line, trying my best to get down the words. Then, I go back and re-evaluate each word, really zooming in on the strokes. The goal is to accurately interpret the writer's intention, especially where the handwriting is less clear. This is where things get tricky. I'm focusing on the context to help to sort ambiguous letters. I'm especially focused on the word 'depends', 'Saying', the "Virgil - or", the "Eden & its purity".

The real challenge is line 21, the parenthetical phrase. I spend a lot of time deconstructing the strokes and considering various word options: "Give," "I've," "smelt," "struck," "seen," "met," "truck," "since" and others. The word "smelt" fits the gunpowder theme quite well. The handwriting itself, and the use of "gun-powder" (with a hyphen) is the key.

The final phase involves polishing, checking for internal consistency and grammatical accuracy, and making sure the transcription follows the HTML guidelines, paying close attention to the requested tags.

[Header]

3

[1880, April 21]

[Body]

fabulous heros - I'll follow
Virgie too with his grand
old hero - while he is forming
the Roman race - but I
cant follow Dido to the
lower world - I am afraid
of that "bourne from whence no
traveler returns" - But often
all, my 'acts' may belie my
words! But this is a holiday
I've caught the inspiration -
"Honor & Shame from no condition
rise" - "A mans a man
for au that" - Magna pars -
Hos verdientos feci, tulit
altin honores - Non si male
nunc, et olim Sic erit -
Si quia novisti rectius istis
Candians imperti; si nun his
utere mecum - Sic mundi
gloria tremoih - You ask, what's
the matter with H -

**My Transcriptionist Mind at Work**

Okay, here we go. I've got this handwritten text, and my job is to transcribe it faithfully, errors and all, while sticking to the rules. First, I’m breaking down the task: I'm a professional transcriber, my mission is to accurately reproduce the text from this image, preserving the original formatting and layout, handling any illegible bits with care, and using specific HTML tags as requested. My output is *only* the transcription, nothing more.

Now, let's dive into the image itself. It's a handwritten letter on lined paper. The handwriting is a bit hurried and cursive, but generally readable with context. There’s a date penciled in at the top, a later addition it seems. The text appears to be English mixed with some Latin phrases and quotes.

Time to work line-by-line:

*   **Line 1**: "fabulous heros - I'll follow". "fabulous" is clear, but "heros" is a bit sloppy. "I'll" is fine, and "follow" looks good.

*   **Line 2**: "Virgie too with his grand". "Virgil" or "Virgie"? The handwriting is looping the end letter. It really looks like "Virgie". The context of the Aeneid is there, but I must transcribe what I *see*. "too with his grand" is fine.

*   **Line 3**: "old hero - while he is forming". "old", "hero", "while", "he", "is", and "forming" are all legible.

*   **Line 4**: "the Roman race - but I". "the", "Roman", "race", "but", "I" are all clear.

*   **Line 5**: "cant follow Dido to the". "cant", "follow", "Dido", "to", "the".

*   **Line 6**: "lower world - I am afraid". "lower", "world", "I am" (looks a bit like 'I m'), and "afraid".

*   **Line 7**: "of that "bourne from whence no". "of", "that", "bourne", "from", "whence", and "no"

*   **Line 8**: "traveler returns". But often". "traveler", "returns", and "But often" (the handwriting made "often" at first look like "after").

*   **Line 9**: "all, my 'acts' may belie my". "all," is clear, the quotes around "acts" are there, "may", "belie", and "my".

*   **Line 10**: "words! But this is a holiday". "words!", "But", "this", "is", "a", and "holiday".

*   **Line 11**: "I've caught the inspiration -". "I've", "caught", "the", "inspiration" and the dash at the end.

*   **Line 12**: ""Honor & Shame from no condition". Quote marks, "Honor", the ampersand, "Shame", "from", "no", and "condition".

*   **Line 13**: "rise". "A mans a man". "rise" (the handwriting looks sloppy here - almost like 'risi' - the quote "Honor and shame..."). "A", "mans", "a", and "man".

*   **Line 14**: "for au that" - Magna pars -". "for", "au" (not "a'") the writing looks like "au" here, "that", "Magna", and "pars".

*   **Line 15**: "Hos verdientos feci, tulit". Latin time! "Hos" or "Hoo"? It actually looks like "verdientos," not "versiculos". The handwriting looks like “verdientos," and I must transcribe what I see. "feci,", "tulit".

*   **Line 16**: "altin honores - Non si male". "altin" (looks like "alter" but is an 'i' at the end) "honores", "Non" (looks like "Non"), "si", and "male".

*   **Line 17**: "nunc, et olim Sic erit -". "nunc,", "et", "olim", "Sic", and "erit".

*   **Line 18**: "Si quia novisti rectius istis". "Si", "quia", "novisti", "rectius", and "istis".

*   **Line 19**: "Candians imperti; si nun his". "Candians",

[Header]

4

[Body]

It's a legal holiday & I've
Caught the inspiration -
Something worse caught
me last year - But I'll
"Shift" - Seriously about
300 of our citizens are off
on a grand Excursion to
Galveston via Gulf
Colorado & Santa Fe. R. R.
Many others - others - my house-
hold with them - are off to a
San Jacinto Picnic at
Independence - only 14 miles -
& I am here writing to
an old true & tried friend -
a much more pleasing
task - Did you ever
read Bill Arp on the
pic nic? He excelled
himself on that fruitful
subject -

**Analyzing this document feels like a methodical climb, doesn't it?** First, I'm noting the obvious: a handwritten letter on lined paper. The cursive is pretty clear, probably late 19th or early 20th century. I'm focusing on the page number: a "4" in the top right.

Next, it's line-by-line time. I am going to try and catch every detail.  "It's a legal holiday & I've caught the inspiration -". Okay, that sets a tone. This guy's on a roll. But then, "Something worse caught...". That's a bit of a puzzle. It's either "me last year -", or perhaps something else entirely. After looking over it for awhile, I'm confident it's "year". I'm looking closely and the descender under the 'h' of "caught" belongs to the next word.

After that, "But I'll 'Shift' -". I have to make a guess at the name of the publication. After that: "Seriously about 300 of our citizens are off on a grand Excursion to Galveston via Gulf Colorado & Santa Fe. R. R." I have to double check for typos, and for capitals. I see two railroads that might require special attention: "Colorado & Santa Fe. R. R.". This is something specific to my area of expertise.

Then: "Many others - others - my house-hold with them - are off to a San Jacinto Picnic at Independence - only 14 miles - & I am here writing to an old true & tried friend - a much more pleasing task - Did you ever read Bill Arp on the pic nic? He excelled himself on that fruitful subject -". This gets interesting. "Others" appears twice - is that a repetition, or some nuance of the wording? "San Jacinto Picnic" is the second detail, which takes my attention. Is it one word or two?

The last detail to check is the repeated "others". It looks like "o-t-h-e-r-s". Is it "others"? It is.

I've got the image.

Here's the final output.

[1880, April 21] 5 Have heard nothing from Pres. G. for some time & regret to hear of his sickness I have been & am beginning to face the folly of "nursing" trouble. I fear that is a lesson he is slow to learn. "Roe & Doe" - Salary $2400 The biggest joke of the season. How do you vote? I never hear a word from Maj. B. Partlow gets letters from Auly but never a word about the family. Maj M goes to Lynchburgh! I have my diagnosis - you shall have it - Your criticism of It is just - I have thought it a long time - you are in a position to know - Of course, you will not spend your vacation at A M C

**The Handwriting's Secrets**

Alright, let's dive into this little historical puzzle. My task? To bring this old letter back to life, to let its whispers be heard again.

First, I need to understand it. It's a handwritten letter, that's clear. The script's a beautiful, old-fashioned cursive, likely from the 19th century. There's a date right up top, `[1880, April 21]`, and a mysterious `5` scribbled in the corner. I have to figure out what's in this thing.

Right, time to go line by line.

*   `[1880, April 21] 5` - Date and a number. Likely a page number?
*   `Have heard nothing from` - Starting normally.
*   `Pres. G. for some time &` - "Pres. G." sounds like someone important. Given the date, maybe President Garfield? That `&` is a classic ampersand.
*   `regret to hear of his sickness` - So this is a letter of concern.
*   `I have been & am beginning` - I was wrestling with this phrase, I thought it was `seen`, which is what I initially thought. But the loop on the first letter, how it connects to the rest...it looks like `been`. Considering the context, "I have been [sick]" works best. The whole letter is now taking shape.
*   `to face the folly of "nursing"` - "Nursing" is in quotes, so it's a specific term.
*   `trouble. I fear that is a` - Sounds intense.
*   `lesson he is slow to learn.` - Some kind of insight or realization, it seems.
*   `"Roe & Doe" - Salary $2400` - A firm, or case maybe? That salary is a significant amount for back then.
*   `The biggest joke of the season.` - What's the joke about? I am curious.
*   `How do you vote? I never` - Personal question.
*   `hear a word from Maj. B.` - Another figure, "Maj. B." sounds like an acquaintance.
*   `Partlow gets letters from Auly` - Ah, a name. That's a good find. "Partlow" is a common surname, but `Auly`? Possibly a family member, or a nickname? I'm going to double check this. Looks like `A` `u` `l` `y`.
*   `but never a word about the family.` - Interesting, it sets the tone.
*   `Maj M goes to Lynchburgh!` - Another location.
*   `I have my diagnosis - you` - Seems like a discussion about health.
*   `shall have it - Your criticism` - There's a conversation involved, then.
*   `of It is just - I have thought` - Another person's thoughts being included.
*   `it a long time - you are` - A connection with someone.
*   `in a position to know -` - It's a personal letter.
*   `Of course, you will not` - I'm assuming it's a family member.
*   `spend your vacation at` - Here we are, another location.
*   `A M C` - Hmmm. Initials, perhaps a location? I'll come back to that one.

So the main theme is clear. This is a personal correspondence. It touches on health, locations, a few names and an inside joke. Time to finalize it.

If you go West - I'm
on that road - if you go
East I'm on the nearest
road there - Come & spend
some time with us -
Some things can be talked
which can not be written -
I am trying to stop repining -
Under a Kind providence I
hope to be alive when this Excellency
has gone to his reward - "What
will the(his) harvest be"
I think I can make serviceable to me
an article of the kind referred to in
my last - I claim to have made a
Success of teaching for 17 years in East
Texas - You knew me at A & M. C.
The School here has increased since
Dec. last from 375 to 450 -
I accepted a chair in A & M C because
it offered me a specialty - Wish I had
it to day - Trust the holiday caught you
Write often -
Your friend J. T. Hand

**Here's how I approached this transcription, step by step:** First, I assessed the task: transcribing a handwritten text image, preserving layout, and using specific HTML tags while only outputting the transcription itself. I also noted that I'm supposed to act as an expert. Then, I analyzed the image. It's a handwritten letter on lined paper with some ink fading and cursive handwriting. I recognized that handwriting will need careful inspection. I proceeded line by line. Each word was carefully examined, accounting for possible misreadings, ambiguous characters, and interlinear insertions. For instance, the word after "his" in line 10, that I interpreted as "Excellency" but marked with uncertainty. I considered words such as "Enemy", "Elder", and "Fellow" before settling on "Excellency" as the strongest candidate based on shape and context. "The(his)" harvest was clearly noted. The words "holiday" and "caught" required close scrutiny to resolve. Similarly, the "Dec." in "Dec. last" was verified as the correct reading. I meticulously checked handwriting features and context. I then refined the transcription. Ambiguities were re-evaluated. "Excellency" was re-checked against alternatives. "Holidays" was compared to "holiday". I verified the "caught" reading. I paid close attention to formatting and structure. Line breaks were preserved using `
` tags. The signature was separated out. I ensured that all HTML tags were correctly used (specifically `

`). Finally, I did a final polish: checking the text against the original, correcting any minor errors, and ensuring that everything was correctly formatted to meet the specific requirements of the output format. I'm ready to output the transcription.
